Monday, May 28, 2007























Congress sends Bush war funding bill
The House and Senate passed a $120 billion war spending bill that had been a primary point of contention between Democrats and President Bush. The bill would fund military operations through at least September. It does not include timetables for pulling U.S. troops from Iraq.
FULL STORY

•  Dems promise to continue war-funding fight
•  Schneider: Dems try to have it both ways
•  Is the troop buildup in Iraq working?


























The Situation Room, weekdays 4 p.m. & 7 p.m. ET
Watch "The Situation Room," anchored by Wolf Blitzer, for complete, up-to-the minute coverage of the day's events. Tune in to "The Situation Room" weekdays from 4 to 6 p.m. and from 7 to 8 p.m. ET.

For a daily sneak preview of the show and an early read on the day's political news sign up for "The Situation Room" daily email newsletter at http://www.CNN.com/situationroom.






















Aide: Deputy AG 'not fully candid'
Former Justice Department official Monica Goodling testified that Deputy Attorney General Paul McNulty was "not fully candid" about the 2006 firings of U.S. attorneys.
FULL STORY






Senate slashes guest worker plan
The Senate voted to cut in half the number of guest workers that would be allowed into the United States under an immigration overhaul backed by the White House.
FULL STORY






Report: Red tape snags Marines' gear
The system for delivering badly needed gear to Marines in Iraq has failed to meet many urgent requests for equipment from troops in the field, according to an internal document.
FULL STORY






Dems hail lobbying reforms 
The House passed limits how lobbyists raise money for members and bar spouses from lobbying lawmakers. Democrats called them the most sweeping reforms in decades.
FULL STORY
